section.title: Introduction
section.para: The best way to learn is by doing, so to learn the concepts of virtual disks we're going to create a 1GiB virtual disk from scratch. This information is applicable to the topic of disks in general, it's value is not limited to virtual disks.
What makes virtual disks any different from actual hard drives? We'll examine this question by creating a virtual disk from scratch.

What does your operating system think a disk drive is? I have a 320 GB SATA drive in my computer which is represented in Linux as the file /dev/sda. Using file, stat and fdisk we'll see what Linux thinks the /dev/sda file is.

Lets start out by looking at what a regular drive looks like to our operating system. Throughout this document the regular drive we'll be comparing our findings against will be a 320G SATA hard drive drive that Linux references as /dev/sda. The following example shows some basic information about the device.

section.para: The term "block" is generally interchangeable with the term "sector". The only difference in their meaning is contextual. It's common usage to say block when referring to the data being referenced and to use sector when speaking about disk geometry. Officially the term "data block" was defined by ANSI ASC X3 in ANSI X3.221-199xata AT Attachment Interface for Disk Drives (ATA-1) ยง3.1.3 as:

listitem.para: This term describes a data transfer, and is typically a single sector [...].
